```{r data}
walmart <- read_csv("../Data/Walmart.csv")

walmart <- walmart %>%
  mutate(Date = as.Date(Date, format = "%d-%m-%Y"),
         Year = year(Date),
         Month = month(Date, label = TRUE),
         Week = isoweek(Date),
         Holiday = as.factor(if_else(Holiday_Flag == 1, "Holiday", "Regular")),
         Quarter = quarter(Date))
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r exploring data}
summary(walmart)
colSums(is.na(walmart))
sum(duplicated(walmart))

# Histogram of Weekly Sales
ggplot(walmart, aes(x = Weekly_Sales)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 50, fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::comma) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Weekly Sales")

```
```{r cleanup}
#Removing sales outliers
Q1 <- quantile(walmart$Weekly_Sales, 0.25)
Q3 <- quantile(walmart$Weekly_Sales, 0.75)
IQR <- Q3 - Q1

walmart_clean <- walmart %>%
  filter(Weekly_Sales > (Q1 - 1.5 * IQR) & Weekly_Sales < (Q3 + 1.5 * IQR))
  

```


```{r data visualizations}
store_sales <- walmart_clean %>%
  group_by(Store) %>%
  summarise(Avg_Weekly_Sales = mean(Weekly_Sales, na.rm = TRUE))

# Weekly Sales Plot
sales_trend <- walmart_clean %>%
  group_by(Date) %>%
  summarise(Average_Sales = mean(Weekly_Sales, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(sales_trend, aes(x = Date, y = Average_Sales)) +
  geom_line(color = "steelblue", size = 1) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma) +
  labs(title = "Average Weekly Sales Over Time (All Stores)",
       x = "Date", y = "Average Weekly Sales")

# Weekly Sales Distribution Plot
ggplot(walmart_clean, aes(x = Weekly_Sales)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 100 , fill = "steelblue", color = "white") +
  scale_x_continuous(labels = comma) +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Weekly Sales",
       x = "Weekly Sales", y = "Count")

# Holiday vs Non-Holiday Sales Plot
ggplot(walmart_clean, aes(x = Holiday, y = Weekly_Sales, fill = Holiday)) +
  geom_boxplot(outlier.color = "red", outlier.shape = 15, alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma)
  labs(title = "Weekly Sales: Holiday vs Non-Holiday",
       x = "", y = "Weekly Sales") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Holiday" = "tomato", "Regular" = "skyblue"))

# Average Monthly Sales Plot
monthly_sales <- walmart_clean %>%
  group_by(Year, Month) %>%
  summarise(Average_Sales = mean(Weekly_Sales, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(monthly_sales, aes(x = Month, y = Average_Sales, group = Year, color = factor(Year))) +
  geom_line(size = 0.7) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma, expand = c(0, 0), limits = c(0, NA)) +
  labs(title = "Average Monthly Sales by Year",
       x = "Month", y = "Average Weekly Sales")

# Weekly Sales vs Unemployment
ggplot(walmart_clean, aes(x = Unemployment, y = Weekly_Sales)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.3, color = "darkgreen") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "red") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma)+
  labs(title = "Weekly Sales vs Unemployment Rate",
       x = "Unemployment Rate", y = "Weekly Sales")
```

```{r timeseires}
Overall_sales <- walmart_clean %>% 
  group_by(Date) %>% 
  summarise(Total_Sales = sum(Weekly_Sales, na.rm = TRUE)) %>% 
  arrange(Date)
#Creating time series
sales_ts <- ts(Overall_sales$Total_Sales,
               start = c(year(min(Overall_sales$Date)),
                         week(min(Overall_sales$Date))),
               frequency = 52)

# Time series plot
autoplot(sales_ts) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma)+
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, color = "darkred")
  labs(title = "Overall Weekly Sales Trend (Walmart)",
       x = "Year",
       y = "Total Weekly Sales")
  
# Plot rolling mean and variance
roll_mean <- zoo::rollmean(sales_ts, k = 12, fill = NA)
roll_sd   <- zoo::rollapply(sales_ts, width = 12, FUN = sd, fill = NA)

plot(sales_ts, main = "Overall Walmart Weekly Sales with Rolling Mean & SD", col = "darkblue")
lines(roll_mean, col = "red", lwd = 2)
legend("topleft", legend = c("Original", "Rolling Mean"),
       col = c("darkblue", "red"), lty = 1, lwd = 2)
```

```{r hypothesis testing}
# Augmented Dickey-Fuller test
adf_result <- adf.test(sales_ts, alternative = "stationary")
print(adf_result)
#	Augmented Dickey-Fuller Test

#data:  sales_ts
#Dickey-Fuller = -6.627, Lag order = 5, p-value = 0.01
#alternative hypothesis: stationary
```

```{r forecasting/modeling}
# Fit ARIMA model
fit <- auto.arima(sales_ts)

# Summary of the model
summary(fit)

# Forecast the next n weeks (Chose 12 because its the first quarter of the next year)
Forecast_Weeks <- 12
forecast_sales <- forecast(fit, h = Forecast_Weeks)

#limiting backlog to make graph more readable
recent_sales <- window(sales_ts, start = end(sales_ts)[1] - .25, end = end(sales_ts))

# Plot forecast
autoplot(forecast_sales, include = 52) +
  autolayer(recent_sales, series = "Actual")+
  scale_y_continuous(labels = comma)+
  labs(title = "Overall Walmart Weekly Sales Forecast",
       y = "Weekly Sales", x = "Time")
```

```{r model validation}

#Residual check
checkresiduals(fit)

# Define training and test sets
train <- window(sales_ts, end = c(2012, 40))   
test  <- window(sales_ts, start = c(2012, 41))

# Refit ARIMA on training data
fit_train <- auto.arima(train)

# Forecast on training set
fc_train <- forecast(fit_train, h = length(test))

# Compare forecast accuracy
accuracy(fc_train, test)
```
